revision.text:
[[File:Geoffrey_Cooper_(RAF_officer).jpg|thumb|right|Geoffrey Cooper]] '''Geoffrey Strickland Cooper''' [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (25 October 1925 - 13 December 2014) was a [[Royal Air Force]] officer of the post-Second World War era who as a fighter pilot saw action in the Middle East and Malaya.<ref name=teleg>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11415839/Air-Commodore-Geoffrey-Cooper-obituary.html Air Commodore Geoffrey Cooper - obituary.] ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', 16 February 2015. Retrieved 19 June 2015.</ref>
In early 1948, Cooper was stationed at Ramat David in Palestine with 208 Squadron when his base came under attack from a [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfire]] of the [[Egyptian Air Force]], destroying two British Spitfires on the ground. Just hours later an Egytian patrol of three more Spitfires attacked again. In the subsequent fight, Cooper shot down one Spitfire, damaged another which a colleague then shot down, and a third was destroyed from the ground.<ref name=teleg/>
In January 1949, while on patrol, Cooper was involved in a fight with Spitfires of the [[Israeli Air Force]] and forced to bail out inside Egyptian territory. He was found by Bedouin tribesmen and returned to his base.<ref name=teleg/>
In 1956, Cooper was involved in actions against communist insurgents in Malaya.<ref name=teleg/>
Cooper retired from the RAF in 1978 as an Air Commodore. He then worked as the air correspondent of the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]''. <ref name=teleg/>
